11. LIMITATION OF LIABILITY

      IN NO EVENT SHALL EITHER PARTY BE LIABLE TO THE OTHER PARTY FOR LOST PROFITS OR ANY CONSEQUENTIAL, SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL, OR INDIRECT DAMAGES OR SUCH OTHER PARTY, HOWEVER CAUSED AND ON ANY THEORY OF LIABILITY, ARISING OUT OF THIS AGREEMENT. THESE LIMITATIONS SHALL APPLY NOTWITHSTANDING ANY FAILURE OF ESSENTIAL PURPOSE OF ANY LIMITED REMEDY. IN NO EVENT SHALL D2'S LIABILITY HEREUNDER EXCEED THE TOTAL AMOUNT PAID OR OWED BY LICENSEE TO D2 UNDER THIS AGREEMENT.
perturbation.explanation: Limitation of liability clauses are critical in contract law. Moving this provision to the confidentiality section buries it in an unrelated context. This could make it more difficult for a party to claim protection under the limitation of liability clause because it is not prominently displayed or logically positioned within the contract.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of contract law regarding conspicuousness and enforceability of clauses.

perturbation.changed_text:
15.1     Governing Law. This Agreement shall be governed by and interpreted in accordance within the laws of the State of New York without reference to conflicts of laws provisions.

      15.2     Venue. The parties agree that any litigation arising out of this Agreement shall be brought in the state courts in Delaware, unless LICENSEE would like to resolve disputes through the state courts of California.
perturbation.explanation: The governing law clause specifies New York law, while the venue clause specifies Delaware. This creates a legal contradiction because it's unclear which jurisdiction's procedural rules will apply. Adding an additional potential venue confuses the situation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of contract interpretation regarding choice of law and forum selection.
